pull.title: depends: Update Qt to version 6.10.2
pull.body:
This PR updates the `qt` package in depends to the most recent version [6.10.2](https://www.qt.io/blog/qt-6.10.2-released).

The update includes many bugfixes that enable dropping some patches.

Additionally, [patches](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/34569#issuecomment-3892793262) for compatibility with GCC 16 have been included.

A [commit](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32709/changes/8f1b55d1d52fb6e44a6d2d34b506f7f309c89ad1) from https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32709 is also included.

committer Hennadii Stepanov <32963518+hebasto@users.noreply.github.com> 1770933348 +0000

cmake: Fix `FindQt` module

The `find_package(Qt .. MODULE REQUIRED COMPONENTS ...)` call must treat
any missing component as a fatal error.

events.message:
cmake: Fix `FindQt` module

The `find_package(Qt .. MODULE REQUIRED COMPONENTS ...)` call must treat
any missing component as a fatal error.

<sub>Task `macOS-cross to arm64`: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/actions/runs/21967077478/job/63459576763</sub>
<sub>LLM reason (âœ¨ experimental): Build failed during the bitcoin-qt target compilation (gmake exited with error 1).</sub>

<details><summary>Hints</summary>

Try to run the tests locally, according to the documentation. However, a CI failure may still
happen due to a number of reasons, for example:

* Possibly due to a silent merge conflict (the changes in this pull request being
incompatible with the current code in the target branch). If so, make sure to rebase on the latest
commit of the target branch.

* A sanitizer issue, which can only be found by compiling with the sanitizer and running the
  affected test.

* An intermittent issue.

Leave a comment here, if you need help tracking down a confusing failure.

</details>

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

Added a commit to update the Windows build notes following @maflcko's [suggestion](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/33906#issuecomment-3554424316).
There are lots of changes here with no explanation. @hebasto Could you please add a bunch of comments?

doc: Update Windows build notes

Cross-compiling Qt 6.10 for Windows requires GCC 13.1 or newer, which
exceeds the currently documented minimum.
See https://doc.qt.io/qt-6/windows.html.

events.body:
> There are lots of changes here with no explanation. @hebasto Could you please add a bunch of comments?

All changes in `qt.mk` aim to produce the same (semantically) `configure` script output as in the master branch.
It seems `test_bitcoin-qt.exe` is failing in the CI.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -156,6 +156,7 @@
 'GDI32.dll', # graphics device interface
 'IMM32.dll', # input method editor
 'NETAPI32.dll', # network management
+'ntdll.dll', # native system services

comments.body: Why? According to `cmake/configure-cmake-mapping.md`, `-dbus-runtime` should be mapped to this. Does it not work?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+Keep compatibility with the current libxkbcommon package
+
+Can be dropped if the libxkbcommon package was updated,
+as that would require a different build system (Meson).
+
+
+--- a/qtbase/src/gui/configure.cmake
++++ b/qtbase/src/gui/configure.cmake
+@@ -182,7 +182,7 @@ if((X11_SUPPORTED) OR QT_FIND_ALL_PACKAGES_ALWAYS)
+ endif()
+ qt_add_qmake_lib_dependency(xcb_xinput xcb)
+ if((X11_SUPPORTED) OR QT_FIND_ALL_PACKAGES_ALWAYS)
+-    qt_find_package(XKB 0.9.0 MODULE PROVIDED_TARGETS XKB::XKB MODULE_NAME gui QMAKE_LIB xkbcommon)
comments.body: What makes it safe to just require the old version? Sure they're not relying on an updated abi?

comments.body: I assume one/both of these reports is no longer relevant? Is upstream aware of the remaining issue?

Otherwise, the configuration step logs the following:
```
-- Configuring done (20.0s)
-- Generating done (1.0s)
CMake Warning:
  Manually-specified variables were not used by the project:

    QT_ENABLE_CXX_EXTENSIONS


```

Related upstream items:
- https://qt-project.atlassian.net/browse/QTBUG-119901
- https://github.com/qt/qtbase/commit/30e04340dac26ebd09f9bc8ceb598e873ab63ba7

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -156,6 +156,7 @@
 'GDI32.dll', # graphics device interface
 'IMM32.dll', # input method editor
 'NETAPI32.dll', # network management
+'ntdll.dll', # native system services
comments.body: I didn't track the exact changes in Windows plugins that link to symbols in `ntdll.dll`.

> Why? According to `cmake/configure-cmake-mapping.md`, `-dbus-runtime` should be mapped to this.

It is not, for some reason. An explanatory comment has been added.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+Keep compatibility with the current libxkbcommon package
+
+Can be dropped if the libxkbcommon package was updated,
+as that would require a different build system (Meson).
+
+
+--- a/qtbase/src/gui/configure.cmake
++++ b/qtbase/src/gui/configure.cmake
+@@ -182,7 +182,7 @@ if((X11_SUPPORTED) OR QT_FIND_ALL_PACKAGES_ALWAYS)
+ endif()
+ qt_add_qmake_lib_dependency(xcb_xinput xcb)
+ if((X11_SUPPORTED) OR QT_FIND_ALL_PACKAGES_ALWAYS)
+-    qt_find_package(XKB 0.9.0 MODULE PROVIDED_TARGETS XKB::XKB MODULE_NAME gui QMAKE_LIB xkbcommon)
comments.body:
> What makes it safe to just require the old version? Sure they're not relying on an updated abi?

1. The commit you mentioned does not state that this is a prerequisite for other changes.
2. `libxkbcommon` 0.9.0 [Release Notes](https://xkbcommon.org/doc/current/release-notes.html#libxkbcommon-090--2019-10-19) list a few changes, including the output of `xkb_keymap_get_as_string()`. Grepping the Qt source code did not find any calls of this function.

> I assume one/both of these reports is no longer relevant?

Right. Removed.

> Is upstream aware of the remaining issue?

Not yet.
